questions.text: Patient with non-retractable ptosis gets corrected due to actions like winking, and chewing:
questions.correct_answer: C. Marcuss gunn jaw winking syndrome
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Marcuss gunn jaw winking syndrome Patients with Marcus Gunn jaw-winking syndrome have variable degrees of blepharoptosis in the resting, primary position. Although Marcus Gunn's jaw-winking syndrome is usually unilateral, it can present bilaterally in rare cases. The wink reflex consists of a momentary upper eyelid retraction or elevation to an equal or higher level than the normal fellow eyelid upon stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscle. This response is followed by a rapid return to a lower position.

Highyeild:

The amplitude of the wink tends to be worse in downgaze . This rapid, abnormal motion of the eyelid can be the most disturbing aspect of jaw-winking syndrome .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Abducent nerve palsy - It has the longest intracranial course of any cranial nerve. Its palsy results in an inability of the abducens nerve to transmit signals to the lateral rectus, resulting in an inability to abduct the eye and horizontal diplopia . Option: B. 3rd Nerve Palsy - The primary symptom is diplopia caused by misalignment of the visual axes, and the pattern of Image separation is the key to diagnosing which particular ocular motor cranial nerve (and extraocular muscle) is involved. With unilateral third cranial nerve palsy (ie, oculomotor nerve palsy) , the involved eye usually is deviated "down and out" (ie, infraducted and abducted) , and there may be partial or complete ptosis. In addition, pupillary dilatation can cause anisocoria (greater in the light), symptomatic glare in bright light, and accommodation deficit that may cause blurred vision for near objects.

Extraedge:

The wink phenomenon may be elicited by opening the mouth, thrusting the jaw to the contralateral side, jaw protrusion, chewing, smiling, or sucking

questions.text: Eyelids contain glands for the secretion of various substances and protection. Match the characteristics to the respective glands of the eyelid : Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b Meibomian glands are also known as tarsal glands and are present in the stroma of tarsal plates arranged vertically. They are about 30-40 in the upper lid and about 20-30 in the lower lid.

Highyeild:

Patients with Meibomian gland dysfunction (posterior blepharitis) have pouting or metaplastic meibomian gland orifices, prominent vasculature crossing the mucocutaneous junction, and foamy or turbid meibomian secretions. Eventual atrophy of the meibomian glands, and rosacea.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Glands of Zeis are sebaceous glands which open into the follicles of eyelashes. Option: C. Glands of Moll are modified sweat glands situated near the hair follicle. They open into the hair follicles or the ducts of Zeis glands. They do not open directly onto the skin surface as elsewhere. Option: D. Accessory lacrimal glands of Wolfring are present near the upper border of the tarsal plate.

Extraedge:

There may be mild to moderate conjunctival infection , the papillary reaction of the tarsal conjunctiva, and inferior punctate epithelial erosions with occasional scarring and

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of diplopia and ocular pain when reading the newspaper. She also has a 3-month history of amenorrhea, hot flashes, and increased sweating. She reports that she has been overweight all her adult life and is happy to have lost 6.8 kg (15 lb) of weight in the past 2 months. Her pulse is 110/min, and her blood pressure is 148/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moist palms and a non-tender thyroid gland that is enlarged to two times its normal size. Ophthalmologic examination shows the prominence of the globes of the eyes, bilateral lid retraction, conjunctival injection, and an inability to converge the eyes. There is no pain in the movement of the extraocular muscles. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Neurologic examination shows a fine resting tremor of the hands. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ with a shortened relaxation phase. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular complaints?

options.label: B
options.text: Systemic hyperactivity of the Levator palpebrae superioris

options.label: C
options.text: Granulomatous inflammation of the cavernous sinus.

options.label: D
options.text: Bacterial inflammation of the orbital contents

questions.correct_answer: A. Glycosaminoglycan accumulation in the Orbit.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glycosaminoglycan accumulation in the Orbit. Glycosaminoglycan (GAG) accumulation in the orbital tissues is one of the main causes of Graves's ophthalmopathy . TSH receptors are expressed in the thyroid gland as well as the intraorbital adipocytes and fibroblasts . TSH receptor antibodies in patients with Grave's disease bind to the orbital TSH receptors and stimulate orbital fibroblasts to secrete GAG and the adipocytes to proliferate. GAGs are hyperosmolar, drawing intracellular/intravascular fluid out into the interstitial space and causing edema of the orbital contents.

Highyeild:

GAG accumulation , edema, and increased adipocytes increase the orbital pressure and push the globe forward, causing exophthalmos, compression of the extraocular muscles, ophthalmoplegia (inability to converge eyes, diplopia, difficulty reading), and ocular pain.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. In patients with hyperthyroidism, the "staring look" is due to sympathetic hyperactivity of the levator palpebrae superioris . However, hyperthyroidism does not increase intraorbital pressure and therefore does not cause exophthalmos, ophthalmoplegia (inability to converge eyes, diplopia, difficulty reading), and ocular pain as seen here. This patient presents with ocular features that are characteristically only seen in Grave's disease. Option: C. Idiopathic granulomatous inflammation of the cavernous sinus is seen in Tolosa-Hunt syndrome , a rare disease characterized by ocular pain and ophthalmoplegia due to pressure on the nerves adjacent to the cavernous sinus (cranial nerves III, IV, V, and VI). Although this patient also presents with ocular pain and features of ophthalmoplegia (inability to converge eyes, diplopia, difficulty reading) , examination shows exophthalmos and features of hyperthyroidism that are not associated with Tolosa-Hunt syndrome . Option: D. Bacterial infection of the orbital contents (orbital cellulitis) presents with proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and ocular pain. Patients with orbital cellulitis typically have a fever, a source of infection (rhinosinusitis, dacryocystitis, acute otitis media), and pain in extraocular movements, which are absent in this patient.

Extraedge:

Grave’s ophthalmopathy, also called thyroid eye disease, is an inflammatory disorder affecting the orbit around the eyes and is characterized by upper eyelid retraction, lid lag, swelling redness(erythema), conjunctivitis and bulging. About 30 % of people with Grave’s disease show some signs and symptoms of Grave’s ophthalmopathy.

questions.text: A patient has unilateral ptosis and diplopia. On examination, there was decreased movement of the eyeball in all directions. The patient also complains of difficulty in reading newsprints. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oculomotor Palsy The third, fourth, and sixth cranial nerves innervate the extraocular muscles that position the globes in the orbits. Extraocular muscle paralysis resulting from lesions in one or all of these cranial nerves results in the failure of one or both eyes to rotate in concert with the other eye. The primary symptom is diplopia caused by misalignment of the visual axes, and the pattern of Image separation is the key to diagnosing which particular ocular motor cranial nerve (and extraocular muscle) is involved. With unilateral third cranial nerve palsy (ie, oculomotor nerve palsy) , the involved eye usually is deviated "down and out" (ie, infraducted and abducted) , and there may be partial or complete ptosis. In addition, pupillary dilatation can cause anisocoria (greater in the light), symptomatic glare in bright light, and accommodation deficit that may cause blurred vision for near objects.

Highyeild:

A painful pupil -involved oculomotor nerve palsy may result from a life-threatening intracranial aneurysm . Therefore, recognition of oculomotor nerve palsy is critical to ensure prompt and appropriate evaluation and treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Myasthenia Gravis -This is a long-term neuromuscular disorder junction disease that leads to varying degrees of skeletal weakness. The most commonly affected muscles are those of the eyes, face and swallowing. It can result in double vision, drooping of eyelids, trouble talking and trouble walking. Option: C. Abducent nerve palsy - It has the longest intracranial course of any cranial nerve. Its palsy results in an inability of the abducens nerve to transmit signals to the lateral rectus, resulting in an inability to abduct the eye and horizontal diplopia . Option: D. Trochlear nerve palsy-The most common cause of congenital trochlear nerve palsies is congenital cranial dysinnervation syndrome responsible for binocular vertical oblique diplopia in isolation.

Extraedge:

3rd Nerve Palsy - The primary symptom is diplopia caused by misalignment of the visual axis , and the pattern of Image separation is the key to diagnosing which particular ocular motor cranial nerve (and extraocular muscle) is involved.

questions.text: Shivamma,70 years old, is brought to OPD by his daughter. It was observed that there is drooping of his left eyelid and double vision. The pupillary examination was normal. What is the cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diabetes Ptosis and double vision with no other features suggest an acquired, isolated 3rd nerve palsy with pupillary sparing . This is seen in ischemic conditions such as diabetes . Diabetes can damage the eyes and can lead to poor vision or even blindness . Damaged blood vessels can harm the retina, causing a disease called Diabetic Retinopathy . In early diabetic retinopath y, blood vessels can weaken, bulge, or leak into the retina. This stage is called Non-proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy . Clinical Features: Blurry/ wavy vision Frequently changing vision Vision loss Poor colour vision Spots or dark strings(also called Floaters) Flashes of light

Highyeild:

Risk Factors causing diabetic eye disease : High blood glucose High Blood Pressure High blood Cholesterol and Smoking. Diabetes during pregnancy (Gestational Diabetes).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The vasoneurium supplies the nerve from outside to inside. As the somatic fibres are located in the inner part of the nerve, these fibres are affected more in the setting of ischemia. The parasympathetic pupillary fibres which run on the outside can remain unaffected (resulting in pupillary sparing). Options: C and D. In compressive lesions , the parasympathetic fibres are affected before any disruption of the motor fibres . So pupillary sparing is not seen.

Extraedge:

Eye Examination Guidelines for Diabetes: Type 1: Yearly eye examination should start within 5 years of diagnosis . Type 2: Yearly eye examination should start right after diagnosis . Pregnancy: Women with Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes need an eye examination before pregnancy or within the first 3 months .

questions.text: Which of the following rule out the possibility of Horner's syndrome in the patient? Exophthalmos Dilation Mydriasis Ptosis Select the correct answer from the given below code:

options.label: B
options.text: Only a and b are true

options.label: C
options.text: Only a and c are true

questions.correct_answer: C. Only a and c are true
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only a and c are true Clinical features of Horner syndrome are Mild ptosis (usually 1-2 mm) as a result of the weakness of Müller's muscle Anisocoria is accentuated in dim light Pupillary constriction to light and near stimuli is normal. Hypochromic heterochromia (lighter colour iris on the affected side); in congenital cases. Mild ptosis (Muller's muscle is affected).

Highyeild:

Ptosis may occur due to compression of sympathetic nerves which supply the Muller's muscle of the eyelid as seen in Horner's syndrome . However, the absence of other significant histories like miosis, anhidrosis or the cause of Horner's syndrome like Pancoast tumour makes this answer unlikely. Reduced ipsilateral sweating (only if the lesion is below the superior cervical ganglion).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Only a is true - no, both a and c are the correct answers. Option: B. Only a and b are true - no, b is a feature of Horner's syndrome. Option: D. Only d is true - no d is a feature of Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of Pancoast tumour presents with left-sided drooping of eyelids, absence of sweating on one side of the face and constriction of the left pupil. A diagnosis of Horner's syndrome is made. Which of the following is incorrect about ptosis-

options.label: A
options.text: Ptosis is unilateral in 70% of cases

options.label: B
options.text: Levator palpebrae superioris is supplied by the sympathetic nervous system

options.label: C
options.text: Pseudoptosis may be seen in phthisis bulbi

options.label: D
options.text: It is linked with anomalies in PATOS1, PTOS2 and ZFH4 genes

questions.correct_answer: B. Levator palpebrae superioris is supplied by the sympathetic nervous system
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Levator palpebrae superioris is supplied by the sympathetic nervous system Levator palpebrae superioris is supplied by the Oculomotor nerve , the third cranial nerve. Muller's muscle, on the other hand, is supplied by the sympathetic nervous system. Both muscles function to elevate the eyelid. In Horner's syndrome, the sympathetic nervous system chain is affected leading to paralysis of Muller's muscle causing ptosis . Characterized by the classic triad of Miosis(Constricted pupil) Partial Ptosis Anhidrosis

Highyeild:

Sympathetic innervation to the eye consists of a 3-neuron arc : First Order - Central sympathetic fibres Second Order - Preganglionic pupillometer fibres. Third order- Post ganglionic pupillomotor fibres

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Ptosis is generally unilateral in over 70% of individuals Option: C. An apparent drooping of eyelids is known as pseudoptosis and may occur due to lack of support as in phthisis bulbi or anophthalmos . Option: D. Ptosis may be due to hypoplasia or dystrophy of the levator palpebrae superioris, and has been shown to be associated with anomalies of the genes PTOS1, PTOS2 and ZFH-4.

Extraedge:

Applied Anatomy of Horner Syndrome : Pancoast tumour Birth trauma with injury to the lower brachial plexus Cervical Rib

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-year-old son with complaints of drooping of both eyelids, however, she doesn't complain of vision loss as the child can perform activities. On examination, 2 mm ptosis was noted by an ophthalmologist. Which of the following is incorrect about treatment modalities of congenital ptosis-

options.label: A
options.text: Surgery is the treatment of choice to prevent amblyopia

options.label: B
options.text: Muller muscle resection is carried out for mild ptosis cases

options.label: C
options.text: In moderate to severe ptosis, with a moderate levator action, levator resection is done

options.label: D
options.text: Fasanella-Servat operation is indicated for severe ptosis

questions.correct_answer: D. Fasanella-Servat operation is indicated for severe ptosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fasanella-Servat operation is indicated for severe ptosis Fasanella–Servat operation is indicated for cases with minimal ptosis of 1.5 - 2 mm . In this procedure, the lid is everted and two curved hemostats are placed grasping the conjunctiva, tarsus, levator and Müller muscle . The hemostats are pulled up; the upper tarsus is excised by double the amount of ptosis, i.e. 4–5 mm.

Highyeild:

A running suture is placed and the knot is buried by bringing both ends of the suture out through a skin wound made in the outer part of the lid fold.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Surgery is the treatment of choice in congenital ptosis and is carried out between 3 and 5 years of age if the ptosis is partial. If the visual axis is covered, at least a temporary procedure should be carried out as soon as possible to avoid sensory deprivation amblyopia . Option: B. For cases with mild ptosis having a positive phenylephrine test , internal conjunctival Muller muscle resection is preferred. Option: C. In moderate to severe ptosis with a moderate levator action, levator resection can be carried out by a conjunctival approach or anterior technique. A 10-mm resection is minimal for congenital ptosis.

Extraedge:

Plication of the levator aponeurosis in moderate ptosis also produces good results.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the Ophthalmology OPD with complaints of double vision for 2 months. Further, she admits to getting tired easily and inability to carry out her work as the day passes but feels better after rest. On examination, drooping of eyelids is present bilaterally, and pupils are 3 mm in size bilaterally, reactive to light. What is the mechanism behind her ptosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Antibodies against myelin sheath of nerve fibres

questions.correct_answer: C. Antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors This is a case of Myasthenia gravis . This is an autoimmune disorder seen mostly in females of age groups 20-30 years which is characterized by generalized muscular weakness and rapidly developing fatigue of the muscles which increases as the day progresses and improves with rest. This is due to damage to the acetylcholine receptors by anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies at the postsynaptic membrane. These antibodies are found in approximately 80% of patients with myasthenia gravis.

Highyeild:

Clinical manifestation : Increasing muscle weakness Affected muscles are -muscles used for the movement of eyes, chewing, swallowing, speaking and breathing In severe cases, respiratory muscle weakness Laryngeal involvement produces dysphonia Ptosis Diplopia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Ptosis may occur due to compression of sympathetic nerves which supply the Muller's muscle of the eyelid as seen in Horner's syndrome . However, the absence of other significant histories like miosis, anhidrosis or the cause of Horner's syndrome like Pancoast tumour makes this answer unlikely. Option: B. A brainstem lesion leading to oculomotor nerve palsy may lead to ptosis but there will be accompanying signs of ophthalmoplegia and signs of other cranial nerve palsies , motor and/or sensory deficits depending on the location of the lesion. The typical history of progressive muscle weakness as the day passes and improvement with rest points towards Myasthenia gravis . Option: D. Multiple sclerosis is a demyelinating disorder with antibodies against the myelin sheath of nerve fibres. The peak onset is between 20-40 years of age and females are more commonly affected. However, it has a relapsing-remitting course which is not seen in this patient. Patients with multiple sclerosis present with a variety of motor and sensory symptoms which may have asymmetrical involvement.

Extraedge:

Diagnosis History and physical examination Blood analysis Elevated levels of acetylcholine receptor antibodies. Anti MuSK (Muscle - Specific kinase) antibody. Tensilon test (Edrophonium test).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with a chronic cough and a history of significant weight loss. He smokes 20 cigarettes per day since the age of 20 years. He is not an alcoholic. He is a known case of diabetes for 10 years on regular medications. He also has unilateral ptosis, loss of sweating and constricted pupil on the right side of his face. Which nerve is responsible for ptosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right-sided sympathetic nerves The symptoms of chronic cough, weight loss and chronic smoking history point to a diagnosis of a lung tumour which may be at the apex of the lung compressing the sympathetic nervous chain leading to Horner's syndrome . This syndrome presents with ipsilateral miosis, ptosis and anhidrosis. Therefore, the compression of right-sided sympathetic nerves is leading to ptosis of the right eyelid .

Highyeild:

Sympathetic innervation to the eye consists of a 3-neuron arc : First Order - Central sympathetic fibres Second Order - Preganglionic pupillometer fibres. Third order- Post ganglionic pupillomotor fibres

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Right-sided oculomotor nerve lesion may lead to right-sided ptosis due to l evator palpebrae superioris palsy, however, with lack of other signs like ophthalmoplegia and the presence of a Pancoast tumour makes the diagnosis of Horner's syndrome more likely. Options: B and D. Left-sided oculomotor nerve lesion and sympathetic nerve lesion would lead to left-sided ptosis which is not present in this case.

Extraedge:

Applied Anatomy of Horner Syndrome : Pancoast tumour Birth trauma with injury to the lower brachial plexus Cervical Rib

questions.text: A 29-year-old is posted for surgery for ptosis of his left eye. Which of the following is true regarding the advantages of levator plication surgery over levator muscle resection?

options.label: D
options.text: Better results in cases of severe ptosis

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Doesn’t require extensive dissection Levator plication is a technique in which the levator muscle is double-breasted over itself. It does not require extensive dissection to isolate the levator unlike in muscle resection procedure . Fasanella-Servat operation is indicated for severe ptosis Fasanella–Servat operation is indicated for cases with minimal ptosis of 1.5 - 2 mm . In this procedure, the lid is everted and two curved hemostats are placed grasping the conjunctiva, tarsus, levator and Müller muscle . The hemostats are pulled up; the upper tarsus is excised by double the amount of ptosis, i.e. 4–5 mm. A running suture is placed and the knot is buried by bringing both ends of the suture out through a skin wound made in the outer part of the lid fold.

Highyeild:

In moderate to severe ptosis with a moderate levator action, levator resection can be carried out by a conjunctival approach or anterior technique. A 10-mm resection is minimal for congenital ptosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Levator plication usually takes less time than the levator resection procedure. Option: C. levator plication has the disadvantage that there is much more lid lag and lagophthalmos following this procedure as compared to resection. Option: D. Levator plication is shown to have poorer results in severe ptosis as compared to resection.

Extraedge:

Plication of the levator aponeurosis in moderate ptosis also produces good results.

questions.text: An 88-year-old man presents to the ophthalmologist with drooping of both his eyelids which is causing problems in his vision. There are no other complaints. On examination, there is the presence of a high lid fold and thinning of eyelids. The rest of the ocular examination is unremarkable. What is the mechanism of ptosis in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Weakness of levator palpebrae superioris aponeurosis due to ageing

options.label: C
options.text: An autoimmune disease affecting the LPS muscle

questions.correct_answer: B. Weakness of levator palpebrae superioris aponeurosis due to ageing
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Weakness of levator palpebrae superioris aponeurosis due to ageing This is a case of Aponeurotic ptosis due to ageing. Aponeurotic ptosis is one of the causes of acquired ptosis which occurs due to weakness or disinsertion of the levator palpebrae superioris aponeurosis from the anterior surface of the tarsus. This is due to ageing, involutional or following recurrent lid oedema or trauma.

Highyeild:

The diagnostic feature is the presence of a high lid fold with good levator action . Sometimes the fold may be absent. The lid is thinned.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The symptom of the patient is bilateral and hence a unilateral right-sided oculomotor nerve palsy will be incorrect. In addition, oculomotor palsy will present with additional signs like lateral and downward gaze due to paralysis of the Medial rectus and superior rectus respectively. Option: C. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder seen mostly in females of age group 20-30 years which is characterized by generalized muscle weakness and rapidly developing fatigue of the muscles. which increases as the day progresses and improves with rest. Anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies are found in approximately 80% of patients with myasthenia gravis. Even though MG patients present with ptosis, the age of the patient and lack of other symptom s makes the diagnosis of MG unlikely. Option: D. A tumour at the lung apex known as the Pancoast tumour compresses the sympathetic nervous system chain leading to Horner's syndrome which is characterized by ptosis, miosis and anhidrosis . However, the lack of other signs and no history suggesting a lung tumour makes this option incorrect.

Extraedge:

Surgery consists of reinsertion of the levator aponeurosis to the anterior surface of the tarsus and appropriate resection of the levator .

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of drooping of both eyelids. All the following are possible causes of pseudoptosis except-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aponeurotic ptosis Aponeurotic ptosis is one of the causes of acquired ptosis which occurs due to weakness or disinsertion of the levator palpebrae superioris aponeurosis from the anterior surface of the tarsus. This is due to ageing, involutional or following recurrent lid oedema or trauma. Aponeurotic ptosis is one of the causes of acquired ptosis which occurs due to weakness or disinsertion of the levator palpebrae superioris aponeurosis from the anterior surface of the tarsus. This is due to ageing, involutional or following recurrent lid oedema or trauma.

Highyeild:

An apparent drooping of the eyelid is known as pseudoptosis and may occur due to lack of support as in phthisis bulbi, anophthalmos, enophthalmos, hypotropia of the eye, dermatochalasis and contralateral lid retraction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Enophthalmos is defined as abnormal retraction of the eyeball Option: B. Phthisis bulbi - in this condition, the eyeball is shrunken and quadrilateral in shape owing to pressure by the rectus muscles Option: D. Dermatochalasis is the presence of loose folds of skin and muscle due to the weakening of connective and elastic tissue with age.

Extraedge:

Surgery consists of reinsertion of the levator aponeurosis to the anterior surface of the tarsus and appropriate resection of the levator .

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of myotonic dystrophy presents to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of drooping of eyelids. He requests surgery for the same due to cosmetic reasons. Which of the following principles behind operative procedures for ptosis is not correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Levator resection if levator action is good

options.label: B
options.text: Frontalis sling operation if levator is paralysed

options.label: C
options.text: Plication of levator aponeurosis in moderate cases of ptosis

options.label: D
options.text: Fasanella Servat operation in cases of severe ptosis with no levator function.

questions.correct_answer: D. Fasanella Servat operation in cases of severe ptosis with no levator function.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fasanella Servat operation in cases of severe ptosis with no levator function. The Fasanella Servat operation is indicated for cases of minimal ptosis of 1.5–2 mm with good function of the levator muscle and a good lid fold. In this procedure, the upper tarsus is excised by double the amount of ptosis i.e . 4–5 mm and a running suture is placed. In this procedure, the lid is everted and two curved hemostats are placed grasping the conjunctiva, tarsus, levator and Müller muscle . The hemostats are pulled up; the upper tarsus is excised by double the amount of ptosis, i.e. 4–5 mm. A running suture is placed and the knot is buried by bringing both ends of the suture out through a skin wound made in the outer part of the lid fold.

Highyeild:

In moderate to severe ptosis with a moderate levator action, levator resection can be carried out by a conjunctival approach or anterior technique. A 10-mm resection is minimal for congenital ptosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Levator resection can be carried out in moderate to severe cases of ptosis with moderate levator action. It can be done by a conjunctival approach or anterior technique . A 10-mm resection is minimal for congenital ptosis and maximal for senile ptosis. Option: B. When the levator muscle is intact but the function is poor, strengthening by resection of the levator is not recommended and the lid is then suspended from the frontalis. This may be carried out by the use of sutures, fascia lata slings or silicon rods. Option: C. In cases of mild to moderate ptosis , the levator can be double-breasted over itself instead of being resected. This technique of levator plication can give good results only if the levator function is good.

Extraedge:

Levator plication is shown to have poorer results in severe ptosis as compared to resection. Plication of the levator aponeurosis in moderate ptosis also produces good results.
